sourceText: Covid-19 Parenting
text: Covid-19 Parenting

sourceText: Scan the QR code for more information from
text: Scan the QR code for more information from

sourceText: www.covid19parenting.com
text: www.covid19parenting.com

sourceText: Just 5 minutes every day can make a big difference. It helps children feel loved and important.
text: Just 5 minutes every day can make a big difference. It helps children feel loved and important.

sourceText: Make a schedule for you and your children that has time for structured activities as well as free time. This can help children feel more secure and better behaved.
text: Make a schedule for you and your children that has time for structured activities as well as free time. This can help children feel more secure and better behaved.

sourceText: Catch difficult behaviour early and redirect your children with something interesting or fun.
text: Catch difficult behaviour early and redirect your children with something interesting or fun.

sourceText: Use positive words when telling your child what to do; like “Please put your clothes away” (instead of “Don’t make a mess”).
text: Use positive words when telling your child what to do; like “Please put your clothes away” (instead of “Don’t make a mess”).

sourceText: Talk to someone when you feel lonely. Take 5 deep breaths when you feel stress or anger. You are not alone.
text: Talk to someone when you feel lonely. Take 5 deep breaths when you feel stress or anger. You are not alone.

sourceText: Spend quality time with your children.
text: Spend quality time with your children.

sourceText: Parenting during COVID-19 can be extra hard. It’s normal to feel stressed and overwhelmed. Here are 6 tips to make things easier for you and your children.
text: Parenting during COVID-19 can be extra hard. It’s normal to feel stressed and overwhelmed. Here are 6 tips to make things easier for you and your children.

sourceText: Create a flexible but consistent daily routine.
text: Create a flexible but consistent daily routine.

sourceText: Praise your child when they are behaving well.
text: Praise your child when they are behaving well.

sourceText: When children misbehave.
text: When children misbehave.

sourceText: Say the behaviour you want to see.
text: Say the behaviour you want to see.

sourceText: Take care of yourself.
text: Take care of yourself.

sourceText: For more information click on the following links:
text: For more information click on the following links:

sourceText: tips from WHO
text: tips from WHO

sourceText: tips from UNICEF
text: tips from UNICEF

sourceText: other languages
text: other languages

sourceText: evidence-base
text: evidence-base

sourceText: Try praising your child or teenager for something they have done well. They may not show it, but you’ll see them doing that good thing again. It will also reassure them that you notice and care.
text: Try praising your child or teenager for something they have done well. They may not show it, but you’ll see them doing that good thing again. It will also reassure them that you notice and care.

sourceText: Partners
text: Partners

sourceText: Funders
text: Funders

sourceText: Millions of children face interruptions with schooling and often feel isolated from friends and peers.
text: Millions of children face interruptions with schooling and often feel isolated from friends and peers.

sourceText: This tip is about learning through play – something that can be fun for all ages!
text: This tip is about learning through play – something that can be fun for all ages!

sourceText: For more information click below links:
text: For more information click below links:

sourceText: Telling stories.
text: Telling stories.

sourceText: Tell your children a story from your own childhood.
text: Tell your children a story from your own childhood.

sourceText: Ask your children to tell you a story.
text: Ask your children to tell you a story.

sourceText: Make up a new story together starting with “Once upon a time…” Each person adds a new sentence to the story.
text: Make up a new story together starting with “Once upon a time…” Each person adds a new sentence to the story.

sourceText: Act out a favorite story or movie – older children can even direct younger ones while learning responsibility.
text: Act out a favorite story or movie – older children can even direct younger ones while learning responsibility.

sourceText: Change the object!
text: Change the object!

sourceText: Every day household items like brooms, mops, or scarfs can become fun props for games.
text: Every day household items like brooms, mops, or scarfs can become fun props for games.

sourceText: Place an object in the center of the room and whenever someone has an idea, they jump in and show the rest what the object can be.
text: Place an object in the center of the room and whenever someone has an idea, they jump in and show the rest what the object can be.

sourceText: For example, a broom might become a horse, microphone, or even a guitar!
text: For example, a broom might become a horse, microphone, or even a guitar!

sourceText: Movement games.
text: Movement games.

sourceText: Create a dance choreography to your children’s favorite songs. First person does a dance move and everyone else copies. Everyone takes turns being the leader.
text: Create a dance choreography to your children’s favorite songs. First person does a dance move and everyone else copies. Everyone takes turns being the leader.

sourceText: “Challenge” who can do the most toe touches, jumping jacks, or laps around the room in a minute.
text: “Challenge” who can do the most toe touches, jumping jacks, or laps around the room in a minute.

sourceText: “Mirror” each other’s facial expressions, movements, sounds. One person can start as the leader and then switch. Try it with no leaders!
text: “Mirror” each other’s facial expressions, movements, sounds. One person can start as the leader and then switch. Try it with no leaders!

sourceText: Freeze dance: Play music or someone sings a song, and everyone dances. When the music stops, everyone must freeze. Last person still dancing becomes the judge for the next round.
text: Freeze dance: Play music or someone sings a song, and everyone dances. When the music stops, everyone must freeze. Last person still dancing becomes the judge for the next round.

sourceText: Animal dance: Same as above but when the music stops, call out a name of an animal, and everyone has to become that animal.
text: Animal dance: Same as above but when the music stops, call out a name of an animal, and everyone has to become that animal.

sourceText: Types of play.
text: Types of play.

sourceText: Learning through Play
text: Learning through Play

text: Covid-19 Parenting

text: tips from WHO

sourceText: tips from UNICEF
text: tips from UNICEF

sourceText: other languages
text: other languages

sourceText: evidence-base
text: evidence-base

sourceText: Singing.
text: Singing.

sourceText: Singing songs to your baby or young child helps develop language.
text: Singing songs to your baby or young child helps develop language.

sourceText: Play or sing a song, and the first one to guess it right becomes the next leader.
text: Play or sing a song, and the first one to guess it right becomes the next leader.

sourceText: Make up a song about handwashing or physical distancing. Add dance movements!
text: Make up a song about handwashing or physical distancing. Add dance movements!

sourceText: Memory game.
text: Memory game.

sourceText: First person says, “When COVID-19 ends, I am going to...” (e.g, go to the park).
text: First person says, “When COVID-19 ends, I am going to...” (e.g, go to the park).

sourceText: Second person adds to first person, “When COVID-19 ends, I am going to the park and… (e.g., visit my best friend)”.
text: Second person adds to first person, “When COVID-19 ends, I am going to the park and… (e.g., visit my best friend)”.

sourceText: Each person adds to the previous trying to think of all of the fun things to do when COVID-19 ends.
text: Each person adds to the previous trying to think of all of the fun things to do when COVID-19 ends.

sourceText: You can change this to any scenario in the future (e.g., when I see my friends).
text: You can change this to any scenario in the future (e.g., when I see my friends).

sourceText: There are many different types of play that can be both fun AND educational.
text: There are many different types of play that can be both fun AND educational.

sourceText: Language, numbers, objects, drama, and music games give children opportunities to explore and express themselves in a safe and fun way.
text: Language, numbers, objects, drama, and music games give children opportunities to explore and express themselves in a safe and fun way.

sourceText: Partners
text: Partners

sourceText: Funders
text: Funders

sourceText: We love our children and teenagers, but stress from caregiving, money, and COVID-19 can make us angry.
text: We love our children and teenagers, but stress from caregiving, money, and COVID-19 can make us angry.

sourceText: Here is how we can maintain control and manage our anger so we do not hurt others.
text: Here is how we can maintain control and manage our anger so we do not hurt others.

sourceText: For more information click below links:
text: For more information click below links:

sourceText: Stop the river at the source.The same things usually make us get stressed and angry every time.What makes you angry? When does it happen? How do you normally react?Prevent anger from starting in the first place. Get some sleep or rest when you are tired. Try to eat something when you are hungry. Ask someone for support when you are feeling alone.Look after yourself. Try the “Take a Pause” and “Managing Stress” resource sheets for ideas.
text: Stop the river at the source.The same things usually make us get stressed and angry every time.What makes you angry? When does it happen? How do you normally react?Prevent anger from starting in the first place. Get some sleep or rest when you are tired. Try to eat something when you are hungry. Ask someone for support when you are feeling alone.Look after yourself. Try the “Take a Pause” and “Managing Stress” resource sheets for ideas.

sourceText: Take care of yourself.
text: Take care of yourself.

sourceText: We all need to connect. Talk to friends, family, and other support networks every day.
text: We all need to connect. Talk to friends, family, and other support networks every day.

sourceText: Cut back on drinking alcohol or don’t drink, especially when the kids are awake.
text: Cut back on drinking alcohol or don’t drink, especially when the kids are awake.

sourceText: Do you have weapons or things that can be used to hurt others? Lock them up, hide them or take them out of the home.
text: Do you have weapons or things that can be used to hurt others? Lock them up, hide them or take them out of the home.

sourceText: It’s ok to have your children stay somewhere safe or take them to a place where they can get help.
text: It’s ok to have your children stay somewhere safe or take them to a place where they can get help.

sourceText: Take a break.
text: Take a break.

sourceText: When you start feeling angry, take a 20-second cool down. Breathe in and out slowly 5 times before you speak or move.
text: When you start feeling angry, take a 20-second cool down. Breathe in and out slowly 5 times before you speak or move.

sourceText: Go somewhere else for 10 minutes to regain control of your emotions. If you have safe outdoor space, go outside.
text: Go somewhere else for 10 minutes to regain control of your emotions. If you have safe outdoor space, go outside.

sourceText: If you are getting angry because your baby won’t stop crying, it’s OK to leave them on their back in a safe location, like a crib, and walk away for a bit. Check on your baby every 5-10 minutes.
text: If you are getting angry because your baby won’t stop crying, it’s OK to leave them on their back in a safe location, like a crib, and walk away for a bit. Check on your baby every 5-10 minutes.

sourceText: The COVID-19 crisis isn’t forever – we just have to get through it now…one day at a time.
text: The COVID-19 crisis isn’t forever – we just have to get through it now…one day at a time.

sourceText: Brain science shows that if you control your anger or do something positive you increase your child’s brain development.
text: Brain science shows that if you control your anger or do something positive you increase your child’s brain development.

sourceText: Be proud of yourself when you manage to do it!
text: Be proud of yourself when you manage to do it!

sourceText: That’s real success!
text: That’s real success!

sourceText: Covid-19 Parenting
text: Covid-19 Parenting

sourceText: When We Get Angry
text: When We Get Angry

sourceText: tips from WHO
text: tips from WHO

sourceText: tips from UNICEF
text: tips from UNICEF

sourceText: other languages
text: other languages

sourceText: evidence-base
text: evidence-base

sourceText: Partners
text: Partners

sourceText: Funders
text: Funders

sourceText: Keeping your family healthy and safe from COVID-19 can feel even harder when you live in crowded conditions.
text: Keeping your family healthy and safe from COVID-19 can feel even harder when you live in crowded conditions.

sourceText: There are things you can do to make this easier for your family.
text: There are things you can do to make this easier for your family.

sourceText: For more information click below links:
text: For more information click below links:

sourceText: Keep using these tips
text: Keep using these tips

sourceText: Help your children with physical distancing.
text: Help your children with physical distancing.

sourceText: Explain to your children that they have an important job of keeping themselves and their community healthy by temporarily physically distancing from others.
text: Explain to your children that they have an important job of keeping themselves and their community healthy by temporarily physically distancing from others.

sourceText: Show them extra positive attention when they make an effort to practice safe physical distancing from others.
text: Show them extra positive attention when they make an effort to practice safe physical distancing from others.

sourceText: Make handwashing and hygiene fun!
text: Make handwashing and hygiene fun!

sourceText: It might be hard to find soap and water, but practicing good hygiene is more important now than ever.
text: It might be hard to find soap and water, but practicing good hygiene is more important now than ever.

sourceText: Try to wash all family members’ hands as often as possible with soap and water.
text: Try to wash all family members’ hands as often as possible with soap and water.

sourceText: Help children teach each other how to wash their hands with soap and water.
text: Help children teach each other how to wash their hands with soap and water.

sourceText: Encourage children to avoid touching their face.
text: Encourage children to avoid touching their face.

sourceText: Keeping positive, having a routine and trying to get some one-to-one time with each child when you can will help you manage your children’s behaviours and your feelings.
text: Keeping positive, having a routine and trying to get some one-to-one time with each child when you can will help you manage your children’s behaviours and your feelings.

sourceText: Take a Pause.
text: Take a Pause.

sourceText: You might not have space to yourself to deal with all the stress and emotions you are feeling.
text: You might not have space to yourself to deal with all the stress and emotions you are feeling.

sourceText: Notice when you are feeling stressed or upset and take a pause…even three deep breaths can make a difference!
text: Notice when you are feeling stressed or upset and take a pause…even three deep breaths can make a difference!

sourceText: Well done! Millions of families find that this helps.
text: Well done! Millions of families find that this helps.

sourceText: Exercise daily.
text: Exercise daily.

sourceText: Encourage children to think of activities they can do to exercise while avoiding contact with people who do not already live in your immediate space.
text: Encourage children to think of activities they can do to exercise while avoiding contact with people who do not already live in your immediate space.

sourceText: Jumping activities, dancing or running in circles can be fun!
text: Jumping activities, dancing or running in circles can be fun!

sourceText: Share the load.
text: Share the load.

sourceText: Looking after children and other family members is difficult in cramped spaces, but it’s much easier when responsibilities are shared.
text: Looking after children and other family members is difficult in cramped spaces, but it’s much easier when responsibilities are shared.

sourceText: Try to share household chores, childcare, and other tasks equally amongst family members.
text: Try to share household chores, childcare, and other tasks equally amongst family members.

sourceText: Create a schedule for time “on” and time “off” with other adults in your household.
text: Create a schedule for time “on” and time “off” with other adults in your household.

sourceText: It is okay to ask for help when you are feeling tired or stressed so that you can take a break.
text: It is okay to ask for help when you are feeling tired or stressed so that you can take a break.

sourceText: tips from WHO
text: tips from WHO

text: tips from UNICEF

sourceText: Covid-19 Parenting
text: Covid-19 Parenting

sourceText: Parenting in Crowded Homes and Communities
text: Parenting in Crowded Homes and Communities

sourceText: Keep staying safe.
text: Keep staying safe.

sourceText: Limit those leaving and returning to your immediate living space to as few and as infrequent as possible.
text: Limit those leaving and returning to your immediate living space to as few and as infrequent as possible.

sourceText: Know the COVID-19 rules about what you can and can’t do in your area.
text: Know the COVID-19 rules about what you can and can’t do in your area.

sourceText: Partners
text: Partners

sourceText: Funders
text: Funders

sourceText: Tips for Children with Disabilities
text: Tips for Children with Disabilities

sourceText: For more information click below links:
text: For more information click below links:

sourceText: tips from UNICEF
text: tips from UNICEF

sourceText: other languages
text: other languages

sourceText: evidence-base IS HERE
text: evidence-base IS HERE

sourceText: It is strongly recommended that you follow local guidelines for COVID-19 while helping your child stay as active as possible both indoors and outdoors.
text: It is strongly recommended that you follow local guidelines for COVID-19 while helping your child stay as active as possible both indoors and outdoors.

sourceText: Ask your local support team or intervention centres about special arrangements for the COVID-19.
text: Ask your local support team or intervention centres about special arrangements for the COVID-19.

sourceText: Keep emergency contact numbers where you can easily see it, such as on the refrigerator.
text: Keep emergency contact numbers where you can easily see it, such as on the refrigerator.

sourceText: Covid-19 Parenting
text: Covid-19 Parenting

sourceText: Be supportive, empathetic, and loving.
text: Be supportive, empathetic, and loving.

sourceText: Your child may not have the same support they usually have, and this can lead to additional challenges such as increased stress, anxiety, and frustration.
text: Your child may not have the same support they usually have, and this can lead to additional challenges such as increased stress, anxiety, and frustration.

sourceText: Use physical and verbal support to make your child feel accepted and loved.
text: Use physical and verbal support to make your child feel accepted and loved.

sourceText: Positive body language, gestures, and words make a big difference!
text: Positive body language, gestures, and words make a big difference!

sourceText: Communicating with your child.
text: Communicating with your child.

sourceText: Keep your child safe.
text: Keep your child safe.

sourceText: Get down to your child’s level when communicating with your child.
text: Get down to your child’s level when communicating with your child.

sourceText: Maintain eye contact, a positive attitude.
text: Maintain eye contact, a positive attitude.

sourceText: Take your time to allow your child the space to communicate.
text: Take your time to allow your child the space to communicate.

sourceText: Observe, listen to, and confirm that you understand your child.
text: Observe, listen to, and confirm that you understand your child.

sourceText: Reinforce the positive!
text: Reinforce the positive!

sourceText: Reinforce strengths with praise and stimulate their abilities rather than highlight the things they cannot do.
text: Reinforce strengths with praise and stimulate their abilities rather than highlight the things they cannot do.

sourceText: Only help children when they need it.
text: Only help children when they need it.

sourceText: Too much support denies them the chance to become independent and can feel patronising.
text: Too much support denies them the chance to become independent and can feel patronising.

sourceText: Ask for help if you can.
text: Ask for help if you can.

sourceText: Share the load with other adult family members.
text: Share the load with other adult family members.

sourceText: You are not alone! Keep connected with people who understand your situation. Share your challenges AND your successes.
text: You are not alone! Keep connected with people who understand your situation. Share your challenges AND your successes.

sourceText: It is normal to feel stressed, frustrated, and afraid at this time.
text: It is normal to feel stressed, frustrated, and afraid at this time.

sourceText: Be kind to yourself and take a break when you need to!
text: Be kind to yourself and take a break when you need to!

sourceText: Tip sheets “When We Get Angry” and “Keep Calm and Manage Stress” have some helpful advice.
text: Tip sheets “When We Get Angry” and “Keep Calm and Manage Stress” have some helpful advice.

sourceText: Strengthen routines.
text: Strengthen routines.

sourceText: Routines help children feel secure and safe. See tip sheet, “Structure Up!” for more info.
text: Routines help children feel secure and safe. See tip sheet, “Structure Up!” for more info.

sourceText: Create a daily routine with activities that are familiar to your child and include some of their favourite activities.
text: Create a daily routine with activities that are familiar to your child and include some of their favourite activities.

sourceText: Help your child connect to friends and family members via phone chats, writing cards, or drawing pictures.
text: Help your child connect to friends and family members via phone chats, writing cards, or drawing pictures.

sourceText: Provide your child with choices so that they have a sense of control. This also increases self-esteem.
text: Provide your child with choices so that they have a sense of control. This also increases self-esteem.

sourceText: Use simple language and clear instructions and nonverbal communication for children who need it (for example: gestures, pictures, and visual aids).
text: Use simple language and clear instructions and nonverbal communication for children who need it (for example: gestures, pictures, and visual aids).

sourceText: All children, including those with disabilities, need love, respect, nurturing, and time, especially during difficult and uncertain times.
text: All children, including those with disabilities, need love, respect, nurturing, and time, especially during difficult and uncertain times.

sourceText: Partners
text: Partners

sourceText: Funders
text: Funders

sourceText: Adolescents may be missing school, friends and socialisation.
text: Adolescents may be missing school, friends and socialisation.

sourceText: It is important to provide them with extra support as well as the space to express themselves independently.
text: It is important to provide them with extra support as well as the space to express themselves independently.

sourceText: Help your teen manage stress.
text: Help your teen manage stress.

sourceText: Teens will get stressed too - sometime from different things than you.
text: Teens will get stressed too - sometime from different things than you.

sourceText: Allow them to express how they feel and accept their feelings.
text: Allow them to express how they feel and accept their feelings.

sourceText: Try to listen to your teen and see things from their perspective.
text: Try to listen to your teen and see things from their perspective.

sourceText: Do relaxing and fun activities together.
text: Do relaxing and fun activities together.

sourceText: Making routines.
text: Making routines.

sourceText: Involve your teen in creating daily schedules.
text: Involve your teen in creating daily schedules.

sourceText: Set goals and rewards together.
text: Set goals and rewards together.

sourceText: Make sure your teen has time to relax along with structured time for chores and schoolwork.
text: Make sure your teen has time to relax along with structured time for chores and schoolwork.

sourceText: Talking about COVID-19.
text: Talking about COVID-19.

sourceText: Involve them in fact finding and listen to their questions.
text: Involve them in fact finding and listen to their questions.

sourceText: Task them with exploring a topic and reporting back to the family from a radio programme, a newspaper article or the internet.
text: Task them with exploring a topic and reporting back to the family from a radio programme, a newspaper article or the internet.

sourceText: Dealing with difficult behaviour.
text: Dealing with difficult behaviour.

sourceText: Talk through the effects of challenging behaviour.
text: Talk through the effects of challenging behaviour.

sourceText: Explore alternatives with your teen and let them make suggestions.
text: Explore alternatives with your teen and let them make suggestions.

sourceText: Decide together on clear and fair rules and boundaries.
text: Decide together on clear and fair rules and boundaries.

sourceText: Praise your teen when they behave well and follow guidelines.
text: Praise your teen when they behave well and follow guidelines.

sourceText: Sharing responsibilities.
text: Sharing responsibilities.

sourceText: Teens appreciate having extra responsibilities. Allow them to choose a special job that helps out.
text: Teens appreciate having extra responsibilities. Allow them to choose a special job that helps out.

sourceText: Create a time during the day where everyone shares one thing that they enjoyed.
text: Create a time during the day where everyone shares one thing that they enjoyed.

sourceText: Share responsibilities equally amongst women/men and  girls/boys.
text: Share responsibilities equally amongst women/men and  girls/boys.

sourceText: Plan creative ways to communicate with friends and family (e.g., writing messages or drawing pictures).
text: Plan creative ways to communicate with friends and family (e.g., writing messages or drawing pictures).

sourceText: Cook a favourite meal together.
text: Cook a favourite meal together.

sourceText: Talk about something they like: sports, music, celebrities, friends.
text: Talk about something they like: sports, music, celebrities, friends.

sourceText: Exercise together to their favourite music.
text: Exercise together to their favourite music.

sourceText: Spend time with your teen.
text: Spend time with your teen.

sourceText: For more information click below links:
text: For more information click below links:

sourceText: Keep your teen safe online.
text: Keep your teen safe online.

sourceText: Involve your teen in creating family tech agreements about healthy device use.
text: Involve your teen in creating family tech agreements about healthy device use.

sourceText: Help your teen learn how to keep personal information private, especially from strangers.
text: Help your teen learn how to keep personal information private, especially from strangers.

sourceText: Remind your teen that they can talk to you whenever they experience something upsetting online.
text: Remind your teen that they can talk to you whenever they experience something upsetting online.

sourceText: Promote kindness and compassion.
text: Promote kindness and compassion.

sourceText: Model kindness and compassion for those who are sick and those who are caring for the sick.
text: Model kindness and compassion for those who are sick and those who are caring for the sick.

sourceText: Share how your teen can make a difference like standing up for someone facing discrimination or helping a neighbor with food deliveries if they live alone.
text: Share how your teen can make a difference like standing up for someone facing discrimination or helping a neighbor with food deliveries if they live alone.

sourceText: tips from UNICEF
text: tips from UNICEF

text: other languages

sourceText: Tips for Parenting Teens
text: Tips for Parenting Teens

sourceText: Covid-19 Parenting
text: Covid-19 Parenting

sourceText: Partners
text: Partners

sourceText: Funders
text: Funders

sourceText: We spend a lot of time indoors with a young baby, and Covid-19 makes it much more intense.
text: We spend a lot of time indoors with a young baby, and Covid-19 makes it much more intense.

sourceText: It is completely normal to feel isolated, overwhelmed, anxious, and scared for you and your baby.
text: It is completely normal to feel isolated, overwhelmed, anxious, and scared for you and your baby.

sourceText: For more information click below links:
text: For more information click below links:

sourceText: Use social media, phone calls, and anything at your disposal to reach out and connect with others.
text: Use social media, phone calls, and anything at your disposal to reach out and connect with others.

sourceText: Take turns with others to care for your baby. Take time for YOU.
text: Take turns with others to care for your baby. Take time for YOU.

sourceText: Sleep when your baby sleeps so you have energy.
text: Sleep when your baby sleeps so you have energy.

sourceText: Sharing is caring.
text: Sharing is caring.

sourceText: Communicating with your baby.
text: Communicating with your baby.

sourceText: Follow your baby’s lead by copying or mirroring.
text: Follow your baby’s lead by copying or mirroring.

sourceText: Repeat and react to their babble or words.
text: Repeat and react to their babble or words.

sourceText: Use your child’s name when you speak to your baby.
text: Use your child’s name when you speak to your baby.

sourceText: Use words to describe what your baby is doing.
text: Use words to describe what your baby is doing.

sourceText: When babies cry.
text: When babies cry.

sourceText: Respond to your baby immediately.
text: Respond to your baby immediately.

sourceText: Check to see what is making your baby cry.
text: Check to see what is making your baby cry.

sourceText: Swaddling or gently rocking can help calm your baby.
text: Swaddling or gently rocking can help calm your baby.

sourceText: Singing a lullaby or playing soft music can be soothing.
text: Singing a lullaby or playing soft music can be soothing.

sourceText: Keep calm and take a break! You can place your baby in a safe place on their back, and then walk away. Be sure to check on your baby every 5 to 10 minutes.
text: Keep calm and take a break! You can place your baby in a safe place on their back, and then walk away. Be sure to check on your baby every 5 to 10 minutes.

sourceText: If you think your baby is injured or ill, call a health service provider or visit a clinic.
text: If you think your baby is injured or ill, call a health service provider or visit a clinic.

sourceText: Babies learn through play!
text: Babies learn through play!

sourceText: Get to your baby’s level and make sure they can see and hear you.
text: Get to your baby’s level and make sure they can see and hear you.

sourceText: Play peek-a-boo, sing songs or lullabies, stack blocks or cups.
text: Play peek-a-boo, sing songs or lullabies, stack blocks or cups.

sourceText: Make music together: banging on pots, playing with rattlers, shaking jars with beans.
text: Make music together: banging on pots, playing with rattlers, shaking jars with beans.

sourceText: Share books together - even at a very early age! Describe what is happening in the pictures. Let your baby explore books with all of the senses.
text: Share books together - even at a very early age! Describe what is happening in the pictures. Let your baby explore books with all of the senses.

sourceText: Learning with your baby.
text: Learning with your baby.

sourceText: Make their environment interesting!
text: Make their environment interesting!

sourceText: Babies respond to stimulation.
text: Babies respond to stimulation.

sourceText: Let your baby explore the world through the 5 senses!
text: Let your baby explore the world through the 5 senses!

sourceText: Be gentle with your children as they learn, but also with yourself as the parent!
text: Be gentle with your children as they learn, but also with yourself as the parent!

sourceText: Just because something didn’t go well today, or you lost your temper, this doesn’t define who you are as a parent.
text: Just because something didn’t go well today, or you lost your temper, this doesn’t define who you are as a parent.

sourceText: Remind yourself of the things you did well today, even if they may seem small.
text: Remind yourself of the things you did well today, even if they may seem small.

sourceText: Covid-19 Parenting
text: Covid-19 Parenting

sourceText: Partners
text: Partners

sourceText: Funders
text: Funders

sourceText: Share with colleagues, friends and family | Spread the word | Keep children safe online.
text: Share with colleagues, friends and family | Spread the word | Keep children safe online.

sourceText: Keep your child safe with open communication.
text: Keep your child safe with open communication.

sourceText: Tell your children that if they experience something online that makes them feel upset, uncomfortable, or scared, they can talk to you and you will not get mad or punish them.
text: Tell your children that if they experience something online that makes them feel upset, uncomfortable, or scared, they can talk to you and you will not get mad or punish them.

sourceText: Be alert to signs of distress.  Notice if your child is being withdrawn, upset, secretive, or obsessed with online activities.
text: Be alert to signs of distress.  Notice if your child is being withdrawn, upset, secretive, or obsessed with online activities.

sourceText: Create trusting relationships and open communication through positive support and encouragement.
text: Create trusting relationships and open communication through positive support and encouragement.

sourceText: Note that every child is unique and may use different ways to communicate.Take time to adjust your message for your child’s needs.
text: Note that every child is unique and may use different ways to communicate.Take time to adjust your message for your child’s needs.

sourceText: For example, children with learning disabilities, may require information in simple formats.
text: For example, children with learning disabilities, may require information in simple formats.

sourceText: Children and teens are now spending a lot more time online. Being connected helps them reduce the impact of COVID-19 and encourages them to continue with their lives… but it also presents risks and dangers.
text: Children and teens are now spending a lot more time online. Being connected helps them reduce the impact of COVID-19 and encourages them to continue with their lives… but it also presents risks and dangers.

sourceText: Cyberbullying from peers and strangers.
text: Cyberbullying from peers and strangers.

sourceText: Spend time with your child or teen online.Explore websites, social media, games, and apps together.Talk to your teen on how to report inappropriate content (see below).Common Sense Mediahas great advice for apps, games and entertainment for different ages.
text: Spend time with your child or teen online.Explore websites, social media, games, and apps together.Talk to your teen on how to report inappropriate content (see below).Common Sense Mediahas great advice for apps, games and entertainment for different ages.

sourceText: Report online violence against children:
text: Report online violence against children:

text: Other resources:

text: Online Risks.

sourceText: Adults targeting children for sexual purposes on social media, gaming, and messaging platforms.
text: Adults targeting children for sexual purposes on social media, gaming, and messaging platforms.

sourceText: Harmful content – violence, misogyny, xenophobia, inciting suicide and self-harm, misinformation, pornography  etc.
text: Harmful content – violence, misogyny, xenophobia, inciting suicide and self-harm, misinformation, pornography  etc.

sourceText: Keeping Children Safe Online
text: Keeping Children Safe Online

sourceText: Covid-19 Parenting
text: Covid-19 Parenting

sourceText: Create healthy and safe online habits.Involve yourchildorteenin creating family tech agreements about healthy device use.Create device-free spaces and times in your house (eating, playing, schoolwork, and sleeping).Help your child learn how to keep personal information private, especially from strangers – some people are not who they say they are!Remind your children that what goes online stays online (messages, photos, and videos).Actively supervise children’s time online, including computers, smartphones, and tablets.
text: Create healthy and safe online habits.Involve yourchildorteenin creating family tech agreements about healthy device use.Create device-free spaces and times in your house (eating, playing, schoolwork, and sleeping).Help your child learn how to keep personal information private, especially from strangers – some people are not who they say they are!Remind your children that what goes online stays online (messages, photos, and videos).Actively supervise children’s time online, including computers, smartphones, and tablets.

sourceText: Tech fixes to protect your children online.Set upparental controls.Turn onSafeSearchon your browser.Set up strictprivacy settingson online apps and games.Cover webcams when not in use.
text: Tech fixes to protect your children online.Set upparental controls.Turn onSafeSearchon your browser.Set up strictprivacy settingson online apps and games.Cover webcams when not in use.

sourceText: Partners
text: Partners

sourceText: Funders
text: Funders

sourceText: Well done! Millions of families find that this helps.
text: Well done! Millions of families find that this helps.

sourceText: Millions are stressed about money because of COVID-19. It can make us feel exhausted, angry, and distracted.
text: Millions are stressed about money because of COVID-19. It can make us feel exhausted, angry, and distracted.

sourceText: Children or teenagers asking for things can cause arguments. It can help them a lot when we involve them with family budgeting.
text: Children or teenagers asking for things can cause arguments. It can help them a lot when we involve them with family budgeting.

sourceText: For more information click below links:
text: For more information click below links:

sourceText: What do we spend now?
text: What do we spend now?

sourceText: Get a piece of paper (or old newspaper or a cardboard box) and a pen.
text: Get a piece of paper (or old newspaper or a cardboard box) and a pen.

sourceText: Draw pictures of all the things that you and your family spend money on each month.
text: Draw pictures of all the things that you and your family spend money on each month.

sourceText: Write next to each picture how much each thing costs.
text: Write next to each picture how much each thing costs.

sourceText: Add up how much money you have to spend each month.
text: Add up how much money you have to spend each month.

sourceText: Build your own budget.
text: Build your own budget.

sourceText: Find a bag of stones or anything with lots of bits. This is your money for the month.
text: Find a bag of stones or anything with lots of bits. This is your money for the month.

sourceText: As a family, decide what you will spend on what, and put the stones on your picture.
text: As a family, decide what you will spend on what, and put the stones on your picture.

sourceText: If you can save even a tiny amount for the future, or for an emergency – it is great.
text: If you can save even a tiny amount for the future, or for an emergency – it is great.

sourceText: Talk about needs and wants.
text: Talk about needs and wants.

sourceText: Needs: Which things are important or must haves for your family to survive? (like food, soap to wash hands, needs for ill or disabled family members).
text: Needs: Which things are important or must haves for your family to survive? (like food, soap to wash hands, needs for ill or disabled family members).

sourceText: Wants: Which things are nice to have but not essential?
text: Wants: Which things are nice to have but not essential?

sourceText: Discuss with your children what things you could try to spend less on as a family.
text: Discuss with your children what things you could try to spend less on as a family.

sourceText: A budget is how we decide what we will spend our money on, even in stressful times.
text: A budget is how we decide what we will spend our money on, even in stressful times.

sourceText: Making a budget together helps children understand that we all need to make hard decisions in difficult times.
text: Making a budget together helps children understand that we all need to make hard decisions in difficult times.

sourceText: It also helps families to have enough at the end of the month, and borrow less.
text: It also helps families to have enough at the end of the month, and borrow less.

sourceText: Your government may be giving money, or food parcels to families during COVID-19.
text: Your government may be giving money, or food parcels to families during COVID-19.

sourceText: Ask about whether places in your community are giving support.
text: Ask about whether places in your community are giving support.

sourceText: There may be help you can get.
text: There may be help you can get.

sourceText: Involve children and teens in making a family budget.
text: Involve children and teens in making a family budget.

sourceText: ClickHEREfor useful resources and support if you are experiencing violence at home
text: ClickHEREfor useful resources and support if you are experiencing violence at home

sourceText: When we model peaceful and loving relationships, our children feel more secure and loved.
text: When we model peaceful and loving relationships, our children feel more secure and loved.

sourceText: Positive language, active listening, and empathy help maintain a peaceful and happy family environment under stressful times.
text: Positive language, active listening, and empathy help maintain a peaceful and happy family environment under stressful times.

sourceText: Use positive language. It works!
text: Use positive language. It works!

sourceText: Tell others what you want them to do instead of what you don’t want them to do: Instead of “Stop shouting,” try “Please speak more quietly”.
text: Tell others what you want them to do instead of what you don’t want them to do: Instead of “Stop shouting,” try “Please speak more quietly”.

sourceText: Praise others to make them feel appreciated and good about themselves. Simple words like, “Thank you for clearing the dinner,” or “Thank you for watching the baby” can make a big difference.
text: Praise others to make them feel appreciated and good about themselves. Simple words like, “Thank you for clearing the dinner,” or “Thank you for watching the baby” can make a big difference.

sourceText: Share the load.
text: Share the load.

sourceText: Looking after children and other family members is difficult, but it’s much easier when responsibilities are shared.
text: Looking after children and other family members is difficult, but it’s much easier when responsibilities are shared.

sourceText: Try to share household chores, childcare, and other tasks equally amongst family members.
text: Try to share household chores, childcare, and other tasks equally amongst family members.

sourceText: Create a schedule for time “on” and time “off” with other adults in your household.
text: Create a schedule for time “on” and time “off” with other adults in your household.

sourceText: It is okay to ask for help when you are feeling tired or stressed so that you can take a break.
text: It is okay to ask for help when you are feeling tired or stressed so that you can take a break.

sourceText: Feeling stressed or angry?Give yourself a 10-second pause. Breathe in and out slowly five times. Then try to respond in a calmer way. Millions of parents say this helps - A LOT.Decide to take a break from arguing when you see arguments building up, and go into another room or outside if you can.See Tip Sheets on “When We Get Angry” and “Keep Calm and Manage Stress”.
text: Feeling stressed or angry?Give yourself a 10-second pause. Breathe in and out slowly five times. Then try to respond in a calmer way. Millions of parents say this helps - A LOT.Decide to take a break from arguing when you see arguments building up, and go into another room or outside if you can.See Tip Sheets on “When We Get Angry” and “Keep Calm and Manage Stress”.

sourceText: Nice things to do together as a family.
text: Nice things to do together as a family.

sourceText: Let each family member take turns choosing a whole family activity each day.
text: Let each family member take turns choosing a whole family activity each day.

sourceText: Find ways to spend quality time alone with your partner and other adults in your home, too!
text: Find ways to spend quality time alone with your partner and other adults in your home, too!

sourceText: Be an empathetic active listener.
text: Be an empathetic active listener.

sourceText: Listen to others when they are talking with you.
text: Listen to others when they are talking with you.

sourceText: Be open and show them that you hear what they are saying.
text: Be open and show them that you hear what they are saying.

sourceText: It can help to summarise what you have heard before responding: “What I hear you saying is…”.
text: It can help to summarise what you have heard before responding: “What I hear you saying is…”.

sourceText: For more information click below links:
text: For more information click below links:

sourceText: We are models for our kids.
text: We are models for our kids.

sourceText: How we talk and behave in front of our children is a big influence on how they behave too!
text: How we talk and behave in front of our children is a big influence on how they behave too!

sourceText: Try to talk kindly to everyone in the family, adults and children.
text: Try to talk kindly to everyone in the family, adults and children.

sourceText: Bad communication between adults in the household can have a negative impact on our children.
text: Bad communication between adults in the household can have a negative impact on our children.

sourceText: The more we practice modeling peaceful, loving relationships for our children, the more secure and loved they will feel.
text: The more we practice modeling peaceful, loving relationships for our children, the more secure and loved they will feel.
